etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in Gabriel Harvey (c1552–1631), scholar and writer. From post-classical Latin probatorius relating to trial or testing, exploratory, relating to approbation, relating to proof from classical Latin probāt-, past participial stem of probāre + -ōrius

definitions: Having the quality or function of proving or demonstrating.
Of or relating to a probation or trial; having the quality or function of testing.
